Bowing to the mind of enlightenment, which is able to be the supreme skillful means,
One attains liberation from birth, old age, death, illness, suffering, and faults.

The mind of enlightenment is briefly explained to have twelve meanings, which are the essence of this treatise. The wise should know them in order, namely, because of the fruit, because of the cause, because of the essence, because of the synonyms, because of the non-differentiation, because of the abiding in the parts, because of the non-defilement, because of the permanence, because of the association, because of the non-performance of benefits, because of the performance of benefits, and because of the single nature.
Among them, the first reveals the fruit of the mind of enlightenment, causing one to see the benefits;
Next, it explains the cause that gives rise to it;
Then, it establishes the characteristics of its arising, and shows the synonyms without differentiation;
In all states, there is no attachment.
Always in accord with pure dharmas.
In the impure stage, there is no effort, but in the pure stage, it can bring benefit. Nirvana is of one nature.
One should know that these twelve meanings are now explained in this treatise in order.
What is called the fruit of the mind of enlightenment?
It is the most tranquil realm of nirvana.
This is only realized by the Buddhas, not by others.
Why is this?
Because only the Buddhas and Tathagatas can completely extinguish all subtle afflictions and heat.
In it there is no birth, because the birth of the aggregates is forever ended;
no aging, because this merit is supreme, perfect, and ultimate, without decay;
no death, because the inconceivable transformation death is forever abandoned;
no sickness, because all afflictions, obstructions to knowledge, and habitual tendencies are forever severed;
There is no suffering, because all habitual tendencies of the ground of nescience that have existed since beginningless time are forever eliminated;
There are no faults, because all errors in physical, verbal, and mental actions do not occur.
This is the cause of not losing the supreme skillful means of the mind of enlightenment, and all merits reach their ultimate and attain that fruition. That fruition is the realm of nirvana.
What is the realm of nirvana?
It is the inconceivable Dharma body, the characteristic of the transformation and dependence of all buddhas.
Because the mind of enlightenment is the cause of the inconceivable fruition, like the beginning of the white moon, I now bow my head in reverence.
Next, a verse says:
It benefits the good dharmas of the world, the holy dharmas, and all buddhas,
The abode is like a treasure place, like the earth, the ocean, and seeds.
Next, the mind of enlightenment is like the earth, because it is the basis for the growth of all good sprouts in the world;
It is like the ocean, because it is the repository of all the precious treasures of the holy dharmas;
Like a seed, it is the cause for the continuous arising of all Buddha trees.
Thus, the fruition of the bodhi mind has been explained.

A verse says:
Its essence is non-attachment, like fire, jewels, space, and water,
Accomplished by wholesome dharmas, like a great mountain king.

Furthermore, it should be known that this bodhicitta, having accumulated causes, has two aspects, namely the aspect of purity free from defilements and the aspect of being composed of pure wholesome dharmas.

In the same way, although the mind of all sentient beings, which is originally undifferentiated, cannot be defiled by greed, etc., yet it becomes pure by being far removed from greed, etc.
The aspect of being composed of pure wholesome dharmas means that this originally pure mind is the basis of all pure wholesome dharmas, and thus it is composed of all pure wholesome dharmas.
It is said that Mount Sumeru is the basis of many jewels, and thus it is composed of many jewels.

The verse says:

The verse says:

Treatise on the Non-Differentiation of the Dharma Realm of the Great Vehicle This treatise is different from the Tang edition and the Song and Yuan editions.
This is the Tang edition, with five characters, four lines, and twenty-four verses, interspersed with a seven-character verse.
Divided into twelve sections, each section is explained.
The commentary by our ancestor Chengguan is the original version.

According to the two versions from that country and the Song dynasty, there are seven-character four-line verses totaling twenty, which are listed together at the beginning and then explained in order.

The first verse says, The dharma realm is unborn and also undying, without old age, sickness, or death, and without the faults of the aggregates. Because it gives rise to the supreme bodhi mind, therefore I now bow my head in reverence.
Now, according to the Kaiyuan Catalog and Chengguan's commentary, this treatise is considered a single translation.

However, although the two versions from that country and the Song dynasty differ from the current version from the Tang dynasty in wording, their meaning is the same, and they must be later translations from after the Kaiyuan era;
but it is not yet clear in which era and by whom they were translated. This needs to be further examined.
Zang of the two treasuries simply considers it a translation by DivÄkara, which is mistaken.
